intro: Halophila lemnopsis, commonly known as the dwarf seagrass, is a marine flowering plant belonging to the Alismataceae family. It is characterized by its small, narrow leaves and is typically found in shallow coastal waters. This species thrives in brackish to saline environments, often growing in dense underwater meadows. Halophila lemnopsis plays a crucial role in stabilizing sediments and providing habitat for various marine organisms. Its reproductive structures are adapted for underwater pollination, contributing to its ecological significance in coastal ecosystems.
